body: Today's buzz is dizzying, barreling prosperity. Skyscrapers are sprouting like Christmas trees, hotels are full, tourists legion. The average price of a Manhattan apartment south of Harlem is $850,000, and buyers must strike like raptors to grab one. Marc M. Goloven, senior regional economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, says that as employment has
title: The Neediest Cases; Prosperity Extends Its Reach, but Not Far Enough to Benefit All

body: Eugenia Sitaras knew she had the winning numbers for half of a $130 million jackpot, but she did not alert New York State Lottery officials right away. ''I had other things to take care of,'' said Ms. Sitaras, 26, a kindergarten teacher in Brooklyn. Ms. Sitaras, who is known as Eve, had lesson plans to prepare and parent-teacher conferences to
title: Teacher Has Arithmetic to Do: What's Half of $130 Million?

body: James A. Hall thought his weekend was going fairly well when he won a golf tournament late last month, leaving the course with a cash prize of $10. As usual, on his way home to Springfield, Pa., he stopped at the Dandy Mini Mart in Wellsburg, N.Y., a Chemung County town on the Pennsylvania border, to fill his Dodge Durango with gas. There, with the
title: $10 Golf Prize Turns Into $65 Million Payoff

body: Manhattan CHELSEA $1.45 million 161 West 16th Street (Jensen Lewis Building) 1-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. duplex co-op in a prewar loft building; keyed elevator, den, fireplace, high ceilings, 900-sq.-ft. terrace, southern exposure; maintenance $1,496, 64% tax-deductible; listed at $1.45 million, 3 weeks on market (broker: Delson-Ginsberg)
title: Residential Sales

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN GREENWICH VILLAGE $925,000 11 Fifth Avenue (Eighth Street) (Brevoort) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,350-sq.-ft. co-op in a postwar building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining
title: Residential Sales

body: Just a year ago, John Q. Adams was holding his aching head and wondering what had gone wrong. The results of a new state math test had just come out, and only 39 percent of the eighth graders at his school in Brooklyn had met state standards. Mr. Adams's students had done better than the abysmal citywide average of 23 percent. But in the
title: Brooklyn School Breaks From the Pack; A Case Study in How State Testing Was Used to Improve Education

body: In New York City, where two-thirds of the registered voters are Democrats, vigorous primaries between Republicans are few and far between. But there is such a contest being waged between two Republicans who are seeking a State Senate seat in a district that includes parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island. The race, in the 23rd Senate District,
title: State Senate Race Features a Rare Republican Primary

body: A 9-year-old boy was sexually abused by a custodian at Public School 127 in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The custodian, Kelly Velez, 29, was arrested yesterday and charged with sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. An investigator said that on May 10, Mr. Velez touched the boy in the bathroom
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; School Custodian Charged in Boy's Abuse
